data.title: World War II Veterans, Warren County Ohio
data.text:
This page is part of the Warren County Ohio GenWeb project

You are our [an error occurred while processing this directive] visitor since 26 January 2005 -- thanks for stopping by!

Warren County World War II Veterans

1 Sep 1939 to 2 Sep 1945 (6 years and 1 day)

"During World War II, the United States had over 16 million men and women who served in the armed forces. The vast majority of them never saw serious combat. The infantry represented just 14% of the troops overseas but they bore the brunt of the fighting on the ground. They suffered 7 out of every 10 casualties and endured hardships and horrors for which no training could ever have prepared them."

from "The War", a Ken Burns documentary that was run as a mini-series on Public Television Stations. The United States suffered over 416,000 casualties during the war

The links below bring you to just few of the thousands of Warren Countians who have served their country.

I will be happy to add your military veteran to the list. Email your information, images, etc. to Arne Trelvik

LINKS

World War II Honor Roll - Warren County

Warren County World War II Army and Army Air Force Casualites

Warren County, Ohio World War II Casualties Army and Air Force at Access Genealogy

Newspaper Clippings

"Largest Draft Call Sends 101 Men To Army," The Western Star (Lebanon, Ohio), Thursday January 7, 1943, page 1A & 3A

"Franklin Stripes and Bars," The Middletown (Ohio) Journal, Monday September 13, 1943

"Honor Roll," Franklin (Ohio) Chronicle, Thursday, September 16, 1943, page ten.

National Archives:

Research in Military Records - Introduction and Links to Resources

How to Request Military Service Records or Prove Military Service

RUMAGGI (back to Index)

Maj. Gen. Louis Jacob Rumaggi (3 Dec 1900 - 7 Apr 1989) US Army, World War II and Korea

Maj. Gen. Louis J. Rumaggi, unnamed paper dated 8 Apr 1989 which says,

"He attended Miami University for one year before receiving an appointment to the U.S. Military Academy at West Point, where he graduated in 1922. He earned an engineering degree at the University of California, graduating in 1927.

He was stationed throughout the Pacific during World War II and also served in the Korean War for 16 months, where he was chief of engineers for the 8th Army. He earned the Distinguished Service Medal while in Korea, and also received two Legion of Merit awards with clusters.

He served in the Army Corps of Engineers for 37-years, retiring in 1959."

Harry T. Russell

STOUTIMORE (back to Index)

Ralph R. Stoutimore (1924-1995)

photo of gravestone at Springboro Cemetery

from 22 Aug 1995 obituary from unnamed newspaper in the obituary Collection of the Warren County Genealogical Society

"He joined the Army Air Corps on his 18th birghday and became a figher pilot (P-47 Thunderbolt), flying 89 combat missions in Europe during World War II. He was a member of the 9th Air Force, 36th Fighter Group, 22nd Fighter Squadron and earned the Distinguished Flying Cross, Air Medal, five Major Battle Stars and the Purple Heart along with other decorations"
